I had an egg scramble with cheddar and potatoes.  The breakfast came with a large portion of potatoes and walnut bread.  My egg scramble was below average, it was too cheesy and had too many potatoes.  The breakfast already comes with potatoes, so it was like potato overload.  The only highlight was the walnut bread.  My bf had some banana walnut pancakes and enjoyed his breakfast.  

The service was miserably slow and I had to keep looking over and signaling the waitress to get her attention.  She was just chatting away with another waitress as if we didn't exist.  She didn't even come out once during our meal to check to see if things were okay.  

The portions are big and the prices are reasonable at Chloe's Cafe.  Unfortunately, that isn't enough to make me want to go back.  I really wanted to like this place, but after that kind of treatment, Chloe's left a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Vivian W.

description:
It was a long wait but it was worth it.  The coffee is amazing!  The egg dishes are creative and tasty.  We also had really yummy seasonal pancakes....pumpkin pie spice...they were delicious!

Would go again...would definitely recommend!
author: Lily B.

description:
Living in the Miraloma/Wportal area GOOD bfast spots are rare and come on you can only go to "squat n gobble" sooo many times before you start to feel ripped off. We gave this spot a try today and I'm very excited. Not excited that they only make scrambled eggs, felt almost sac religous...but hey after a mimosa or two I didn't care how my eggs were coming. (aoooow). 

So read the review below on the banana walnut pancakes and had to have them and did. So worth the wait baggage and won't be doing this every weekend but see you guys in a few months. Got their early enough to sit within 5 mintues but parking..eh not so great. 

I'd do the pancakes, mimosa isn't too worth it but the pancakes make it all worth it.

PS NO credit cards allowed....
author: Gen O.

description: Great food, service, and atmosphere. Wish they had a tofu scramble and took cards though. Banana pancakes are pretty amazing.
author: Morgan O.

description: Came here this past Saturday with a friend and my two kids.  It's a very cute but small breakfast place.  I was worried that it might not be kid friendly.  But I was worried for nothing.  They sat us withing 15 minutes (pretty good for the amount of business they had). The kids were comfortable and the service was excellent.  I loved my food and I'm coming back for sure.  The only reason I'm giving it a 4 stars instead of 5 is because I didn't know they didn't take credit.  Part of it could be my resposibility because I should ask, but nowadays I think people should post that they don't take credit.  But that didn't matter that much since the food and the service were 5 stars.
author: Rose R.

description: Pretty average meal. It has nice outdoor seating and you can ask them to put the umbrella up.
author: E T.

description:
Chloe has wonderful pancakes and eggs.

I went there with a friend and was lucky enough to get the outdoor seats on a beautiful day. Got seated within 5-10 mins after we put our name on "the waiting list" (there was barely people waiting at that time)

after, we got our food, my friend and I cannot stop saying how good the restaurant was, how delicious the food was.... My friend even said she thought the pancake was way better than the one at Mama's

when our server brought the check, I said, "The food was good."
The server replied, "Better be because you have to wait for it."
And I said, "Hm... no. Actually, we got seated right away."
He said, "You're lucky," and then he looked behind his shoulder.
A good number of people crowd in front of the waiting list table.
author: Cliff T.

description:
this morning, my husband and I went for brunch.  We've eaten at Chloe's many times.  Although we enjoy the food, my emphasis is on the service today.  
   We were cared for--choice  of words deliberate--by two lovely, efficient ,friendly, polite and most delightful Asian-American women. Believe me,  this is some of the best service/care we have received anywhere.  No one spent undue time with us,nor fawned over us, just treated us politely, with interest.  These two young women positively made our morning!  I trust the owner reads these critiques.  As business owners ourselves, we would hire these ladies in a minute;  they could always acquire the necessary skills later.  What they possess is people skills, which cannot be "taught later".  They were, today, the face of Chloe's, which is great for business, as well.    Hence, the fifth star--it's for them.
    Location is good for us, food is good, although I find the scrambled eggs a bit dry this am.  Hubby had scrambled eggs with deli ham, okay;  delicious home fries, walnut bread most delicious, as was the jam.  My avocado BLT was really, really scrumptious, and the vinaigrette some of the best I've had, anywhere in the world, which includes all of Western Europe.
    Although we'll be back to Chloe's, I'll wager these lovely ladies will have long moved onward and upward.  
    Thank you, ladies, and by extent ion, Chloe's, for a very nice morning.

Sincerely yours,

        Marilyn and Jim Murdock
author: Marilyn M.

description: Cute little neighborhood cafe. We were visiting my sister so this was a welcome change to the "touristy" places people usually go.  We got there later so we missed the crowd. walked right up to a table outside. The french toast was really good. I actually ordered a salad and it was very tasty. I have to say, though, my son ordered a turkey sandwich and it was something I could have gotten anywhere, nothing special. I would definitely stick to the breakfast/brunch items the next time I go.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Please don't come here. I mean really...you want to stay far a way from this place. 
Here are a couple of great reasons from highly disappointed Yelpers.

SF Gal says, "I don't understand why people wait so long to eat such less than mediocre breakfast." http://www.yelp.com/biz/chloes-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:wpMxWK46uIrbQqPUlIzamA

Yeah. Thank you, SF Gal...wait in a line for this? You tell themYelpers to eat else where. Leave little neighborhood joints alone. I'm all for that!! Go eat at....errr...Stacks!

Girl N says, "This place is FLITHY DIRTY". http://www.yelp.com/biz/chloes-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:K3lt39s82in8dMpqLzlw3g

Yeah, you are right Girl N. We completely prefer your kitchen counter! 

So, all you Yelpers, please don't come here for breakfast/brunch. Please leave me and my rent-a-friends to eat our "less than mediocre" breakfast.

You absolutely do not want to enjoy the breakfast dishes listed below. Trust me.

Banana walnut pancakes ($8.95) - Not icky sweet. Deliciously fluffy and perfected with just the right amount of nuts and bananas. I usually share this dish and one pancake puts me in banana NUT heaven.

Bacon and Tomato Scramble ($7.75) - The wheat toast that comes with this dish isn't the pre-sliced kind. I absolutely love the texture of the wheat bread covered with their delicious jam. Deelish!! As for the scramble, the balance of the ingredients is perfecto!

Grilled Rice and Tomato on Croissant ($6.95) - Creatively awesome!!

Coffee - Meh. But, drinkable.

I can see how waiting outside for 35-45 minutes can really make your breakfast affair a one time fling. You keep saying to yourself or friends. "Damn, this better be worth it." I experience that at Mama's. So, what I suggest is just don't come here or Mama's. Simple. ;-P

Overall: The service was consistent. My OK coffee was continuously topped off as well as my cool glass of water. The food was great for my taste buds. The décor was modest, but the outdoor seating surely does rock. Dogs allowed outside. The wait does suck. It's a cash only place, but with an ATM right across the street.
author: Liz K.

description:
I used to love this place; in fact I've brought many a friend or family member in for brunch but I can assure you that I will not be back after my experience today.
A few minutes after my mother in law and myself were seated we realized there was only one menu on the table. I waited a few more minutes for someone to notice or bring one but after realizing that it was an oversight I walked over to the waitress-tall, heavy set brunette-and asked her for a second menu.
She gave me the nastiest look and didn't say a word and slapped one down in my hand. I dont know if she was having a bad day but I dont think I deserved the attitute.
The other server wasn't much better-she also seemed to be having a really bad day but c'mon people if you work in the service industry get it together.
The worst part of our experience, however, came when I found a thick black curly hair in my albacore tuna salad; it looked like a pubic hair and I was so disgusted that needless to say I couldn't finish my meal.
I didn't even bother saying anything to the waitress in large part because no one came by to check on us during our meal and by the time they finally cleared our plates my mother in law was long finished. Also, after the "tude" I got from a mere asking for a menu, I didn't really feel like the headache and decided I just wouldn't be returning again.
What a dissapointment from what I used to consider a really fantastic little spot in the neighborhood.
author: Glowy L.

description:
When I first spotted Chloe's, I knew we were in for a treat. Any good brunch-goer knows the bigger the crowd outside the door, the better the brunch, and there were a good 30 people standing around on the sidewalk. It was already 1 p.m., but my friend and I decided to take our chances -- by the time we were seated an hour later, my stomach was growling like mad.

The food was absolutely worth the wait! I ordered the special -- scrambled eggs with artichoke, red peppers, fresh zucchini and feta, with house potatoes and walnut wheat toast. The food was impeccable, and the house-made jam was so good I had to ask if they bottle and sell it (nope). The actual place is super cute too, especially when you can sit outside in the sun, street-side.

I docked a star because the servers weren't very friendly, and my mocha didn't taste like a mocha at all, even after they tried to fix it. Also, the bathroom had dirty water all over the floor. Ew. 

Still, I feel lucky to have found yet another mind-altering, thank-god-you're-alive brunch spot in the city.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Way back when, Fred the dawg used to try to drag my ass over here from Potrero for brunch on the weekends.

A- 'Why the hell for?'
F- 'You'll see when we get there.'
A- 'Is the food good?'
F- 'It's alright.'
A- 'Then why the hell are we going all the way over there?'
F- 'Try it, you'll like it.'
A- 'Aw crap, look at the line.'
F- 'Yeeeeeah. Look at it.'
A- 'Man, that's not funny. I'm HUNGRY.'
F- 'Don't worry, I'll buy you lunch after.'
A- 'After what? Breakfast?!'
F- 'Yeah.'
A- 'WTF?'

Why girls like it:
Fresh-n-yummy breakfast fare in cute portions. The fruits, juices, toasts are particularly good, as is the sausage (though at $3-4 a link, it had better be)

Why guys like it:
The girls like it.

Why girls should be wary of an invite from a guy to eat here:
He's trying too hard. He's also suppressing hunger-likely to be cranky later.

Why guys should be wary of an invite from girls to eat here:
You are being tested. Suck up the wait. Focus. Converse attentively. Clean your plate. Maintain eye contact. Don't complain openly about the portions or lack of egg options. Pay the tab. Head straight to lunch. Do not pass 'Go'.

BTW, my sweetie never put me through this one. Breakfast is too important.
author: Andy R.

description:
Everything Fancy S. said.  There has GOT to be a plastic surgery clinic somewhere down the street.  This shit is funnier than our foreign policy.  OH YES SHE DID!!!

Delicious home fries.  Actually fresh fresh fruit.  Excellent Salads, too!  You can sit with your dog outside (yay!).  It gets super crowded though so make sure to get there early or to go with someone fabulous you don't mind wasting the day away with.  Like Fancy S.  Awww...
author: Laura B.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon for brunch. I went with hard scrambled eggs with extra cheddar, onion, potato, avocado and bacon. DEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEELICIOUS. 

This place is really cute and the food is AWESOME. I hear their coffee is really good but I forgot to try it. 

Eugy thought he was being all sofistimacated by pronouncing the name of this place "Sho-lay". He was talking about it for a good 5 minutes but I couldn't figure out what he was saying. He was like, "you know, the place we went for brunch. Sholay. Sholay. Sholay." 

Poor Eugy. He tried. He really did.. ;)
author: Jen D.

description:
Just got back from brunch at Chloe's. Based on previous reviews we both ordered the Strawberry Cinnamon Croissant French Toast and it was AMAZING- Definitely will return for the pillowy soft layers inside and delicious flavor. 

The Chicken Apple Sausage was also delicious- the most flavorful I've ever had and the scrambled eggs (w/cheddar) were okay, not bad but not anything to write home about . If it were possible I'd only deduct a half star for the scrambled eggs. 

Helpful hint: Arrive early. We got there at 10:10 AM and we had to wait 15-20 minutes to be seated. Get here as close to 9 AM as you can... although the food will be well worth the wait.
author: Dom J.

description:
After walking across the city (I'm glad it's only 7x7), I met up with some people for brunch.  Luckily, they got there about 20 minutes before me so they had a table by the time I arrived.

The restaurant is small and the tables are kind of close together but I didn't care because it was bright and cheerful looking.  

I went with the dill egg salad sandwich and it was fantastic.  I wasn't sure how to eat it because it was open faced and huge with a bunch of veggies everywhere but I worked it out.  I also tasted the various scrambles and potatoes that people got and everything was delicious.

The coffee was great and the service was efficient.  I'll be back.
author: Seong P.

description: Love this little neighborhood brunch place. Be prepared to wait in line if you come here on the weekends. Every time I want to try something new but I just can't seem to forgo the smoked salmon bagel plate. I just love it too much. The salmon is so fresh and they give you a generous plate. Delicious. My friends had some egg dishes and they all liked it.
author: Yun Y.

description:
Against my better judgment I went along with the suggestion to eat at Chloe's Cafe for breakfast (actually the suggesting party had to say they would pay before I relented) - now if it would have been a weekend, I would have flat refused since I just don't get off on lines for breakfast food no matter how 'good' it is...

Let me start off by saying that I am something of a breakfast purist...I don't care if you serve Rosemary crusted home fries or Walnut cinnamon toast...flat-out that just doesn't float my boat...I know, I know go to Denny's then...well since it's not just me that I have to worry about I make sacrifices and head out to the hoighty-toighty breakfast eateries from time to time. All of that aside, I will say that the breakfast that I had at Chloe's exceeded my expectations. The Blueberry pancakes were very thick and delicious the home fries (which I normally hate because they are never crispy enough) were quite delicious and the Rosemary whatever white bread that became my toast was crusty and delicious - on the negative side they do not have enough egg options to satisfy a true breakfast lover...Would I go on the weekend? Not if I had to wait, would I go back again on a weekday? Absolutely! 

I would like to point out that you should bring cash as they don't take cards but other than that minor annoyance (Side note/Rant - I hate this new cash only trend that I am seeing in the smaller eateries and bars as it is very inconvenient to get cash a lot of the time and not knowing that you need cash before you get there induces me to a minor rage as I scurry to try and avoid having to do dishes - End Rant) I would recommend Chloe's to couples looking to go and have a nice 'coupley' little breakfast in a cute neighborhood...beware the cute couple/cute baby factor here it's libel to send you into a too sweet/too cute overload if you are not prepared.
author: Todd E.

description:
out-of-the-world pancakes!!! banana-walnut?!! *DROOL and I don't even like bananas!!! lol

only sucky thing is the wait time :\ also, no cards! Its tiny (which adds to its charm, naturally) so not good for groups!

but the pancakes? an airy fairytale ;)
author: P G.

description:
Hmm... I'm not sure about the hype.  Definitely decent and fresh and friendly -- but none of the food stood out as being exceptionally good.

Also - the place is tiny and the wait gets long... not sure I would consider that worth it, though as I said nothing fundamentally bad/wrong about it either.
author: S C.

description:
Chloe~ you will always hold a fond place in my heart. Granted the wait was longer than expected, but when you're with good company, you hardly even notice. 

Your mimosas are excellent, your breakfast was amazing... Cinnamon Croissant French Toast with fresh Strawberries, need I say more? My bacon tomato scramble was perfect, I couldn't have made it better myself. And while your food and service are both very much worth mentioning, you will always hold a place in my heart because it was here that I learned about HIM!!!!! BTW, if someone close to you ever wants to go to brunch to catch up... don't put it off.  

Anyways, bring cash because they don't take credit.
author: Chum L.

description: I came to Chloe's for Sunday brunch and it was okay overall. I thought the service was great, and the place was very cute. They only do scrambled eggs here which was already kind of a knock on them for me and the home fries tasted like fish. That was the bad side of the meal. On the great side of the meal was the home made sausage, and the banana walnut pancakes. We also got the ham, cheese and sun-dried tomatoes on a croissant which were was amazing. So overall I thought a 3-star rating was fair for this place. If I came back I'd skip breakfast and get more lunch-type items.
author: Ken C.

description: This was a cute little breakfast nook to try but to be honest the food did not taste as good as it looked. After seeing all these pictures of the strawberry covered crossant french toast I thought I couldn't go wrong, but it was not sweet enough for me and the fried potatoes I had was not all that good either. Parking wasn't bad but I was so disappointed that it did not taste as good as it sounded and looked.
author: Jackie T.

description: L O V E D it. Cozy quarters (not the best for groups or kids but perfect for a date or catching up with a friend). Big portions (I ate the rest for lunch). I had the avocado + Jarlsberg omelet with home fries and toast. So good I'm still dreaming about it. Wait staff was very friendly and my glass stayed full. There was nothing that could have made this place better. Go there.
author: LORI F.

description:
Probably the best pure brunch place in Noe Valley.  The best thing on their menu, by far, is the croissant french toast.  If I were a high school girl I would say "OMG" right now.  It's really, really good, and you can optionally get it covered with fresh strawberries (which I recommend only during strawberry season.... whenever that is).  Other menu highlights include really tasty pancakes and delicious egg scrambles.

I really want to give them five stars, but I can't because they don't take credit cards.  When Chloe's gets in to the 21st century, I'll be happy to update my score.

One other thing to keep in mind is that the place is pretty small, so get there early on the weekends or expect a long wait.
author: Chad H.

description:
This is one of my 2 fav breakfast places in my hood. The other is Pork Store.

I usually get the red potato scramble here. I've tried other things, but I keep coming back to this - I crave it! 

My main tip is when asked which bread option you want, opt for the croissant. They are always incredibly good, warm, crisp and buuuuuttery. I finally asked where they come from (didn't think this tiny place was making them) and then everything made sense: Il Fornaio (the famous Italian bakery).

Some people also say that eggs always taste better here - that might be bc they use actual eggs - not eggs out of a milk carton. I know this bc I cut through the kitchen to use the bathroom and saw all of the shells in the garbage. I do this work for you people.
author: Shal J.

description:
I'd been here two or three times before and had a good experience (good food, good service) so it was a natural pick for meeting friends for brunch a couple of weekends ago. We had to wait awhile, which we'd expected, so no problem there. But the wait wasn't over when we got seated. It took forever for someone to come and take our order. Finally, we got our orders in--three of us had items from the specials menu, and one person had a regular item. No special orders or extra additions. The food came promptly enough, but it was the wrong orders--the server had somehow misunderstood us. That would have been fine--just send it back and adjust. But the server felt the need to come over and tell us that it was our fault: "well, when I asked you what kind of toast you wanted, it's because that's what comes with the combo." As if we were supposed to know the menu well enough to know that toast comes with the combo, but not with the pancakes? I don't know why she was so defensive about it, since it really wasn't a big deal. But she was completely exasperated, rolled her eyes at us, and then marched off. She didn't make another appearance until the end, and other servers filled in for her. When she gave us the bill, she did apologize, in exactly the way she might have done in the first place: "Sorry about that; I'm not sure how that happened." But at that point she really did have something to apologize for, whereas with messing up an order, it's so not a big deal that an apology is really just a formality. It just felt like she was trying to redeem her tip.

Also, the pancakes weren't even anything special--the batter is too dry. I usually get one of their scrambles, which I really like, but the pancakes are really not worth the price.

Probably won't be coming back here anymore, which is too bad because it's a nice spot and close to home.
author: K M.

description:
Chloe's is my new favorite breakfast place!  I basically wake up, brush my teeth, throw on whatever is near my bed and walk over for breakfast.  Some days the wait is 2 minutes and some days the wait is 30 minutes.  But it's ok because I know it's going to be good.

Out of all the times I've been there, I continue to order the same item-
bacon (super crispy and in bite sized pieces), tomato (not over cooked, so perfectly warmed) scramble with a side of fresh avocado (no lemon needed to preserve it) with a bagel.  

I'm a creature of habit and Chloe's doesn't disappoint.
author: Valarie A.

description:
Wah, wah.  Baby had to wait in line for brunch on a weekend in San Francisco.  Poor baby.

Jesus, we San Franciscans are sure a bunch of pusses some times.  Swear.  We have it SO tough.

Chloe's has the best (tie: Boogaloos) breakfast in San Francisco.  If there's a line, just put your name down.  If you're like 10th on the list, stroll the lovely stroll up to Martha & Bros.  Get a cuppa.  Split a bagel with your honey to stave off the rumblies.  Stroll back to Chloe's.  Wait 10 minutes for your table.

Order the scrambles (stellar) or French toast (solar).  The juice and coffee are terrif.  Or clutch.  I was going to start using clutch again this year, so there ya go.

I am just sad that I no longer live 5 blocks away (moved from Noe to Ruski Hill last month)

But I'll be back.  See you there!
author: Scott W.

description: I went to Chloe's today for the first time. After the first time of looking at the reviews on Yelp, I've been dying to try it. It was fantastic! The wait for a Saturday didn't seem bad, I came around 12:45 and waited about 15 minutes for a group of 4. I ordered one of their specials; the BLT sandwich with avacado and a side order of home fried potatoes. It very filling and cost $9.89. The waiters came around to refill our water consistently[; I wanted to try their pancakes, but it seemed a little expensive for my liking.
author: Selena M.

description:
I have discovered the secret to Chloe's...go about an hour before they close for the afternoon, get a table in the sun and bring a puppy.  People are so much nicer to you when you have a puppy in tow.  I had no idea!

Today's special scramble had roasted yellow peppers, onions, broccoli and cheese.  The potatoes were deliciously crispy.  The white rosemary bread was perfectly toasted and the jam was yummy.  Good coffee, too.  My friend got the chef's salad, which was so enormous that she took half of it home for later.  Anyway, I was pleasantly surprised about everything.   I'm going to have to add Chloe's back in to my regular rotation.

The puppy was well-behaved, lots of people stopped to talk to us and pet Peanut, it was a beautiful sunny day and everything was right with the world.  It's too bad I'm only puppy-sitting, I could get use to this lifestyle!
author: Becca V.

description: Good breakfast, but I don't know that I'd wait in line every weekend like people seem to do.
author: J K.

description:
Chloe's in Noe was very disappointing.  I found the wait to be seated quite ridiculous after receiving food that I could have cooked at home.  We ordered the pancakes and egg combo off the menu (the pecan pancakes for me; the ginger pumpkin pancakes for him), and we just couldn't understand what the fuss was about.  I guess it IS possible to have too many pecans, and the scrambled eggs were sad and rubbery.  Prior to coming here, I was told to order the cinnamon croissant French toast, and was really sorry that I didn't.  Nothing irks me more than ordering the wrong thing!

To make matters worse, one of the bus boys carried out a huge garbage bag in the middle of our breakfast, and paraded the damn thing right through the middle of the restaurant for everyone to see.  Ick... Don't they have a back door?

There are too many other wonderful breakfast places with an equal wait but with better food in this city.  Sorry, but no, Chloe...
author: Kira K.

description:
It's hard to choose just one thing at Chloe's. The banana pancakes, croissant french toast, scrambles, muffins, huge ass salads and sandwiches are all pretty tasty. Luckily, my wallet is always low on cash so I let that determine how much food I order. If they took credit cards I'd be happy though. 

The only down sides to Chloe's are the wait and the bathroom. That's not enough to make me knock 'em down a star though.
author: Shara H.

description:
Remember the HOMEMADE banana nut bread that your wonderful grandma used to make? Well ... go to Chloe's and order their banana walnut pancakes and take a trip down memory lane.

They were so good that I dare to say the pancake had a G-spot ... something your grandma's best didn't even do for ya. 

Okay ... wait ...

If you're a woman ... you're probably thinking, 'this guy knows about g-spots? No fuckin way ... they NEVER seem to be able to find it.'
Answer: that's a wholenother conversation we can have later, but let's just say both my friend(very familiar with her G-spot) and I agreed that these lovely pancakes did indeed have a G-spot where all the walnuts and soft slices of banana had secretly joined forces in order to provide about FIVE highly concentrated and explosively enjoyable bites of PURE BLISS.

If you're a man ... go take lessons from the chef, he seems to have no problem identifying and thoroughly educating others on the wonders of the G-spot!

DO NOTE:
1. This cozy restaurant seats 16 people, so if you're looking for a quick in and out, there more than likely are other restaurants(Denny's) that will serve your purpose.
2. The mimosa's are where it's at ... screw bloody mary, wait ... oops ... that's sacrilege,  say NO to blood mary and ask for a mimosa!
3. CASH or PERSONAL CHECK ONLY!
4. Do I get an award for the most usage of "G-Spot" in a restaurant review?
author: Chris S.

description:
The perfect brunch:  egg scrambles, champagne cocktails, great walnut wheat toast, and choice of fruit instead of potatoes.
The lunch menu is also great - the Chloe's salad is the perfect big fat salad.  
The waits can be ridiculous - it's great, but not wait-for-45-minutes great. Don't forget it's cash only.
author: Kelli R.

description:
I'll start this review by laying it on the table that I had high expectations going to Chloe's since it was recommended by friends and it always has a crowd  

I grabbed a coffee while waiting.  The coffee was disappointing.  Drip coffee doesn't have to be watered down and acidic.  But in this case, it was.  We took a table outside and a nice waiter brought us menus and place settings.  The menu is pretty limited, scrambled eggs, but none that are poached, fried, sunny sides, or any others.  I ordered the Avo and Jarglsberg scrambled eggs.  They were good but the bagel that came on the side was hard as a rock.  The potatoes were nicely seasoned.  

This is a nice brunch option but I'm not sure it's worthy of all the hype.  Seems like the Noe brunch crew is blinded by the organic, whole grain toast.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Enjoyed this more than Pomelo, but much more expensive than i expected for what we got.  The meal was tasty (i got an egg scramble and Amanda got french toast), but nothing stellar, and we ended up paying more than $40 without any drinks.
author: Phil J.

description: Great food, service, ambiance and location!  The f line stops right outside.  The pancakes and eggs are perfect!  You do have to wait outside, but you can get coffee while you wait.  Also, they are CASH ONLY, but well worth the trip to the atm.  We will come back again!
author: Elizabeth T.

description: love the jarslberg and avocado omelette - I get it every time
author: Amin S.

description:
I try to roll out of bed early on the weekends and head to Chloe's before the lines start. Not too hard since it's a few blocks from my house. All downhill. The pancakes and french toast are worth being seen with insane bed head. If you go for lunch, the dill egg salad or warm smoked trout sandwiches are great on their rosemary bread. Sit outside, get a glass of wine (hey, it's the weekend) and ignore those standing in line. 

TIP for you those standing in line: do not wait underneath the big tree outside. The pigeons will see you as a big poo target. Seriously. I have never seen more pidge poo.
author: Pam D.

description:
3.5 because the wait was FREAKIN' LONG! One hour, standing in the freezing fog is NOT fun...But I'll round up to four stars. The service is very friendly and this place is one of my sister's favorite places to eat breakfast...

The food was pretty good. I had the scramble special last time I went, with potatoes, and toast. My husband had the french toast with strawberries. All of it in large portions and very hearty. 

The coffee was endless and had just enough intensity for my taste. (I'm not much of a Peet's girl. I opt for the "mild" roast at Starbucks when I go. I guess you could call me a "light weight" when it comes to coffee.)

But just be prepared to wait. The inside of this place is small, and people take their time to eat. On a nice day, I suspect that the wait is shorter, since they've got quite a few tables outside. 

Oh and I think this place is best for a party of 2; 3 people max.
author: Caroline C.

description: Great little neighborhood cafe worth the visit even if you're not from the hood. Usually it's sunny in Noe Valley and Chloe's has great sunny seats all day. The food is just the right mix of traditional and unique. Prepare to wait on weekends, but no probelm since I'll say again, it's usually sunny in Noe Valley.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Chloe's respects the egg - it always comes out soft and sumptuous - never runny with that slimy clear stuff. They have this scramble with avocado and Jarlsburg cheese that  is absolutely perfect. Their whole wheat walnut toast is really really good. 

Small, homey ambiance. Can be quite crowded, so be prepared to wait.
author: Melinda K.

description:
Anybody who make french toast out of croissants and then smothers it in butter is a dear friend of mine. Choe's is #2 of my list of the best damn breakfast spots in San Francisco. It's quaint and intimate...a perfect spot for a leisurely Sunday morning breakfast with someone you love. Afterwards, make sure you leave some time to go home, cuddle-up with that someone and slip into a cholesterol coma....
Why does the acquisition of congestive heart failure have to be so delicious??? WHY???? OOOOHHHHHHHH WHY??????
author: Kathryn E.

description:
reviews are really high for this place, bit over rated (i think). 
the food is ok, portions are good, prices are high and there is a lot of "do nots" at this place. for example, do not substitute unless you want to pay a higher price. the cafe is really small and finding parking sucks. services is really good.  dont bother with their coffee as there are so many coffee shops within 1 block .
author: Cee B.

description:
I went to this place for b-fast.

THE WAIT:
Sucked so bad, probably waited 30 - 40 mins for a table. 

THE FOOD:
The food was about as good as it gets for eggs and potatoes.
author: Michael S.

description: Great breakfast! Food and service is fantastic. Sometimes there is 15 min wait, especially weekends, but it is well worth it. Not your typical eggs and potatoes. If you are a breakfast lover in the area, this is a must try!
author: Ashley M.

description:
Not that I don't love it when my friends announce my sexual proclivities to a large group (ahem you're reading this and you know I'm talking to YOU!), but I do have to say it for myself - THIS RESTAURANT IS THE G-SPOT OF BREAKFAST PLACES! Mmm, pancakes, omlettes, mint tea, fantastic rosemary toast and those dainty 2-person tables.....fixating on that spot again!

For those of you who don't make it out to Noe that often because, I know, the stroller to independently mobile person ratio is way to high and really there's not much going on there in the after daylight hours to make the trek worthwhile, i will say that it's definitely worth waking your ass up one morning and heading over. But beware, don't bring more than 4 people because you will all become way more intimate with the J-line schedule than you ever needed or wanted to be!
author: Nicolle C.

description:
Superp service that's almost out of style. 

I do my fair share of eating out in SF. I generally like the service I receive, but when I ate at Chloe's moderately priced cafe for breakfast on a Tuesday morning, I felt like a king!

"Would you like more coffee sir? Top it off? No no let me get you a fresh cup!"

"splitting appetizers? Shall I bring them on separate plates? Very good, with the other dishes or before?"

Ok so perhaps I'm not providing the most tantalizing examples, but go, enjoy, be treated well and leave full!
author: Christopher S.

description:
Breakfast that isn't greasy?  Is it possible?

At Chloe's it is.  And tasty too!
author: Steve S.

description:
A friend took me here while I was visiting SF.  It was very good, but since I'm a fan of sweet breakfasts, I would have liked more interesting options.  The cinnamon croissant french toast was very good, however.  Apparently this place is the s**t when it comes to scrambles, and there were plenty of options and they looked and smelled delicious. 

If you live in SF I'd definitely say hit it up.  If you're just visiting, maybe explore some other options, though if you end up at Chloe's you'll certainly be happy.

For those unaware, you have to sign a list outside to wait for a table.  We got there and a couple that was ahead of us apparently didn't realize, and went in to take a table that freed up.  They were, indeed, next, however because they didn't sign the list the proprietor's asked them to get up and "wait their turn".  I appreciate their sticking to the rules - the patrons were kind of pissed and left, but it just meant we got our seats sooner!  Oh well :)
author: Sarah C.

description:
I am so stuffed right now I can hardly move my fingers to type.  I just ate some of the best eggs that I have ever had.  For such a tiny little place, the menu is extensive.  You don't actually HAVE to be a little piggy like I am, but I highly recommend it.  

I went on a weekday, and there was a slight wait, so I can only imagine what it is like for weekend brunch.  But absolutely worth it.  The staff is friendly and efficient, and ok with special requests (like please burn my bacon!).
author: Amme P.

description: The wait sucks, especially when it's cold outside, but I wait because it's worth it. I go for the crossaint french toast. Who would have ever thought that french toast doesn't have to be on "bread." I LOOOOOOOOOOOVE french toast, I can eat it breakfast, lunch and dinner so I can tell you the difference between mediocre french toast and bomb-diggity french toast! And let me tell you, this was bomb-diggity. My sister ordered the spinach, mushroom omlette and it was perfectly fluffy with a huge portion of home fries. If the wait wasn't that long, I'd come more often. The plus side is parking isn't that bad. I hope they expand so they can seat more people to decrease the wait time.
author: Nancy Y.

description:
Excellent pancakes here, both the plain and banana nut. Don't eat too much or you'll feel sick. 

Remember to bring cash. Cash only. :(

(Manager, if you are reading, change this! Credit is king! And so are reward points!)
author: G J J.

description:
delicious breakfast. everything tasted really fresh. we all ordered variations of the special so i can't recommend anything specific on the regular menu. but i'm sure it would all be the same quality.

it's in a nice quite area so the outdoor seating is great. service was good.

it's a nice place to grab a bite without the hustle and bustle of the rest of the mission.
author: danielle m.

description:
I've came here a couple of times and each time as impressed as the first.  Friendly staff, cute little cafe.  I'm not really a breakfast person but I would wake up early just for the coffee and home fries.  

The scrambles are always good with generous portions, the rosemary toast is always really good.  

The croissant french toast with strawberries is perfect, not too sweet, not too heavy.
author: Jen L.

description:
Their croissant French toast topped with fresh strawberries is just TOO good for words.  Normally I like salty breakfast food (i.e. eggs, sausage, bacon) but I ALWAYS order the French toast when I come to Chloe's.  Deliciousness to the extreme.

And I've never had a problem with the service or wait.  Maybe because I go on weekdays, and everything is always fabulous.
author: jackie m.

description: I have no idea why this place gets the wait it does. It's not bad, but the food is pretty boring and bland. We have gone early twice  to beat the crowed and it's been blah both times.
author: Joe K.

description: Their eggs are amazing! There is always a wait on the weekend but it's worth it. I don't really like lunch options but you can't go wrong with their eggs or French toast. I'm a regular. Note: Cash only.
author: Claire R.

description: Brunch was solid but nothing to write home about.  They do have a handful of tables outside that seem to be dog friendly for when the sun is out.
author: Barndi K.

description:
The food is delish, but the cafe is very small, so you may need to wait awhile for it.  It's sunny and cute and charming.  

*Not* a hipster joint (if you care), but more of a "dog-owning/baby-having/deck-refinishing/married -couple" kinda place.  Good to go to when you're feeling stable and grown-up.
author: Karen F.

description:
I love this place! I've been there twice with different people and they've also been very pleased. It's crowded but definitely worth the wait. The banana-walnut pancakes are fantastic and their home fries are extra yummy. It's a dog friendly neighborhood, so while you wait you can play with cute puppies and friendly dogs. If you sit outside, you can have you dog at your feet. 

The service is good - nothing notable and nothing to complain about. The prices are very reasonable and I'm definitely going to be a regular at this place.
author: Mary R.

description:
Chloe's is definitely on my short list for brunch!

The Good: pure and simple ingredients - I had the breakfast combo and my friend had an omelette, but we also admired the big scrumptious croissants and the amazing-looking french toast; quaint space on a corner location; friendly service; good price point (I don't feel like I need to "earn" the the visit by living on cereal and milk for a while); and all in cute Noe Valley neighborhood.

The not-as-good: not for large parties (perfect for 2-3); wait time can be long so it really wouldn't be fun during your average blistering SF day.  And remember, cash-only!

I'm looking forward to going back with a read in-tow and a craving for more delish brunch.
author: Carol K.

description:
I don't get the Cult of Chloe's either. 

Only scrambled eggs. You can't ask for egg whites, even if you assure them that your size 12 booty isn't anoerexic, but instead has high cholesterol. And the potatoes are seasoned but oily and not crispy. As far as eggs and potatoes go, I'd say Chloe's is at or below Denny's level. 

I don't remember what it was that I ate beyond that, so it couldn't have been that memorable. 

And clearly, so many disagree with me. But for no wait, patio seating, and much better egg options, try Fattoush brunch the next block south.
author: Lilly I.

description:
Even in the pissing down rain, I had no problem waiting for my first Chloe's scramble. In my old hood, we would go to Ella's or the Curbside on California for breakfast--Chloe's kills them both with fresh ingredients, great service, and the smarts to mix it up a bit. I went traditional and had the diced ham scramble and a delicious berry bran muffin. It was yummy.

Yes, we waited about 30 minutes, but during that time I had some coffee, and I stared at the people who were just seating at their table for 20 minutes after their meal--reading their newspapers--not caring that others were waiting outside in the rain. Oh yeah, Chloe's is in Entitlement Valley. My mistake. But that is no reason not to go invade their turf and eat at Chloe's. I did!
author: Deborah S.

description:
Chloe's is the epitome of a SF neighborhood breakfast place.

The inside is quite small and yet still charming. You're likely to bump into someone if you're not careful getting out of your seat. Servers glide about like ballerinas. 

There's like a wait during busy times (Sunday brunch) and people just wait about on the sidewalk enjoying the Noe Valley sun.

They have outdoor seating and it's common to see couples with babies and children here.

I wouldn't make a trek just to come here and the fare is pretty standard (yet very delicious and healthy) but it's the type of place you fall in love with if you live in the neighborhood. The owners and servers are also the most courteous you'll find in the city.
author: Pete C.

description:
the 5 star is for consistence.

This place has been around forever, and the food has never missed.  I have been going here for 10 years, and seriously, never miss.

Yes there is a wait (go late) and if you are outside you are on flimsy metal tables.

But the flavors run deep and it strikes a balance between casual and finessed food.

Best pick:
Red potato scramble with a croissant.
author: Ken p.

description:
In one word...charming. 

Chloe's is a charming and consistent cafe. The food is always tasty and the service is reliable. Their pancakes and breads look amazing but I tend to go for their scrambles. 

The menu and food is simple. This is not the place to go for cutting-edge breakfast food. I tend to like multiple ingredients in my egg dishes, but Chloe's simplicity is refreshing. I enjoy sitting outside to avoid the lack of space indoors. Also, they don't mind if you bring your dog!

Although not a culinary adventure, Chloe's remains on my breakfast list.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
This place always has a line, weekday or weekends, why? 
Because people are friggin' cheap asses.  
Breakfast here is CHEAP but good.

My husband and I always chuckle when we walk past this place.
The food is very good, and the prices are very cheap.  
Some other reviewers state the food is 5 stars, do they only eat at Big Boy's??
Again, scrambled eggs, and french toast..
Everytime I walk past this place, I think to myself, PEOPLE, why are you waiting an hour to eat breakfast, go to Savor, or Toast or Le Zinc, all in walking distance and eat now.  
People are eating outside, with all the other sheep standing a foot from their table. It is literally disgusting to eat your brunch, with someone's ass is your face.  
But- alas if you enjoy that, more power to ya.
if you do eat here, get he scrambled eggs, with avocado an fontina cheese.
author: Pug P.

description:
Great food in a really cute place! The boy and I went during the week to avoid the crowds, so waiting really wasn't a problem. 

I got the croissant french toast with strawberries, and he got the scrambled eggs with smoked salmon. Everything was fresh (strawberries!), and tasted great. Maybe a little too great. Unfortunately for me, the boyfriend enjoyed his food so much he chose to respond to whatever conversation I was trying to make with full-mouthed "umpguh"s and grunts. That didn't end up being too much of a problem, though, because the big windows allowed for great dog people watching! 
I love me some Chloe's!
author: MC F.

description: The service is slow but the food more than makes up for it. Try the pancakes with a side of bacon and a cup of coffee, you won't be sorry. Be warned: it is cash only... and they ONLY do scrambled eggs. They are, however, delicious.
author: Barbara F.

description:
How to properly enjoy Chloe's:

1. Do not go on Saturday or Sunday between 9am-2pm

2. Do go any day during the week or order takeout

3. Order Pancakes. The Banana Walnut pancakes have huge chunks of perfectly ripe bananas. The Blueberry pancakes are so full of blueberries that they ooze juice all over your plate. The Ginger Pumpkin pancakes are the perfect fall pancake. All of them blow away any pancakes I have ever had anywhere else, ever, and I've eaten lots of pancakes.

4. If there are pancakes on the special, order them. This will only happen during the week. The latter two of the above pancakes are specials. The kind people who work at Chloe's have told me before that they only do the pancake specials during the week. I don't know if this is actually true or if they were just lying to try to get me to come during the week when they're not so damn crowded.
author: Amber C.

description: The lovely location is Chloe's best asset: lots of sunshine and indoor/outdoor seating. The coffee drinks are also pretty good for a food-focused place. Unfortunately, everything else here is oddly bland. Ho-hum dishes that are frankly mediocre for the price. Their egg options are limited for a breakfast place, but nothing stands out about their scrambles. Pancakes, potatoes, sandwiches, sausage, french toast--as well as the service--all forgettable. One tiny bathroom for a very popular place.
author: Stella S.

description:
Such a cute, homey place to have brunch or lunch. A friend took me here for a birthday lunch. We arrived during the peak lunch hour on a weekday and ended up waiting about 20 minutes.

When we got inside, we sat at a table that was meant for two people (there were three of us). When it's full, the place is pretty cramped, but the food is fresh and good. My friend told me the Dill Egg Salad sandwich was good so I took her rec and it did not disappoint!

I would definitely come back. The drawbacks (hence 4/5 stars) to this place is long wait during peak eating hours, parking difficulty and spotty service due to a full crowd.
author: Janel Y.

description:
No, not the most amazing meal I've ever had, but definitely better than average (where are those half-stars?).  Well-balanced coffee drinks (just right espresso:milk), BUTTERY pancakes with additions that make me want to fiddle with my pancake recipe at home when I feel like cooking.

I can't imagine sitting inside unless it's foggy, and since I go at strange times I don't have to wait.

I'd say this place is more dog-tolerant than dog-friendly.  I've learned to bring the portable water bowl and ask for extra waters.
author: Angela C.

description:
- A little expensive for a starving college student, but not for most others.

-"Fresh orange juice" is not, in fact, fresh squeezed orange juice. It kinda tasted like Tropicana or something.

- Got the Pancake, scrambled egg, and fresh fruit combo for just under 10 bucks.

-Pancakes were just divine. They were banana walnut and they were maybe the best I've ever had.

-Eggs were also very high quality. Not much you can say about eggs, unless they're bad.

- Fresh fruit was hella fresh. Really good strawberries.

-Overall, a great experience. Really nice day and we sat outside.

One kinda bad thing, they don't take credit, only cash, but there is an ATM in the corner store across the street.
author: Samuel K.

description:
Went here for the first time this weekend.  The weather was fantastic and we sat outside.  The scrambles were really well done.  Perfect proportion of everything and eggs were still light and fluffy.  I had mine with gruyere, chicken apple sausage, and mushrooms.  Muy tasty.  And their homefries are bomb.  We waited for about 30-40 minutes but it was worth it (especially given the weather).

I'll definitely be back.  It doesn't have the selection of Mama's but it does have the same homey feel and quality dishes.
author: Courtney N.

description:
3 Stars because the food is superb and some of the servers are wonderful.  The salad, if tossed, is perfect.  If not, it goes all over the place.  Unfortuntely..

Problem, last summer... they did it (the 30 second salad toss) every time I went, but the final time I went they said it's against their policy.  When I politely reminded them that I'd had it that way many times, this younger server who I'd never had before said "look, we're slammed."  I said fine, I'll have something else (this time).  I didn't decide in 2.5 minutes when she came back out and she got in my face, then sent someone else out, who was nice (-er) , but did not concede.  Everything else took forever from there on out, and now, though I'd been there many times, I decided that time would be my last.  I don't go to restaurants to get punished and feel awkward.  Plain and simple.  I'm a man of manners and patience, but I don't easily forgive evil bitches who claim to be "servers' but do not serve anything but attitude.  The guy who runs it is awesome, the location is fun and the space is comfortable.  The food is great and again why this place gets 3 stars and not 1.  However, Chloe's really hurt my feelings that day.
author: Jack M.

description: I had the cinnamon crossaint french toast with strawberries and the house coffee. It was actually very good but inline with other reviews as over priced. The wait was about 30 min on a sat morning which isnt too bad.
author: Genaro R.

description: Good location. Nice place to eat outside, but the food is okay. Good prices though. So overall, good spot to catch up with friends for a reasonable priced brunch but was not spectacular.
author: Susan B.

description:
YUM---E!

Scrambled eggs with red potatoes, red onions, and cheddar.  Toasted croissant, fresh fruit, orange juice (not fresh squeezed), and perfectly crunchy biscotti.  

There is no better way to have brunch on a Tuesday morning when there is NO wait and no silly people being arses about waiting :)

Oh and the jam was delish.

My only food blah is that the potatoes were a little hard for being in soft eggs, knowwhadamean?

Boo for it being a little cramped, tables were tiny, restroom was right next to food being cooked, and I really wasn't digging staring at myself while I was eating--just a personal pref :)
author: avisha c.

description: Hands down favorite brunch place in the city. Everything on the menu is delicious, and the wait isn't that crazy (usually no more than 20-30 min at peak brunch times). Portions are excellent and prices are very reasonable too.
author: Jeff C.

description: Cute and quaint by all means, great service....but the food is not out of this world. Nor are there much stellar breakfast options in my opinion. I have never tried the lunch fare and I should and update when I do. In general I say good, but best in the city-- no.Get there early or prepare to wait
author: Lauren V.

description: This place is so cute! The service is wonderful, the food is as good as my grandmother's, and the energy is very cozy. I love this place!
author: Marie F.

description:
It's a really cute place in Noe Valley, and I had brunch here today with some girlfriends. I had a garden veggie scramble with jarlsberg cheese. Big points for the strawberry preserve, which was home made and was great with the nutty wheat toast, which was kind of artisan style bread.  The home fries were very good, but could have used some more something, so I put some salt on it and ate them with hot sauce and ketchup. The scramble was.... just ok. The service was very good. 

Overall... it didn't blow me away, but I'd come here again.
author: Oiyan P.

description:
Randomly stumbled upon this place years back when I first moved to the city.  The Ogre and I were hungry for brunch so we decided to pick a random spot nearish to my Bernal Heights apt.  Oh boy, it was a heavenly find.  I've taken many-a-visitors back here since that fateful day and they all love it.  Anything with jarlsberg is yummy!  The scrambles are fluffy.  The fruit is fresh.  The rosemary toast is delightful and so is the homemade jam.  It's like eating in someone's cute little country kitchen with super nice servers!

There is always a bit of a wait on the weekends.  The last time I was here was around 10am on a drizzly San Francisco morning and there was already a line.  Just bring good company and you won't mind the wait.
author: Lynda N.

description: The place is really small so there was a little bit of a wait. There are a couple of menus to look at while you are waiting. The food here was really fresh tasting and savory. Croissant French Toast with strawberries was tasty! Service was not great but not bad either. The service keeps me from giving this place 5 stars. I will definitely go back and eat again.
author: J D.

description:
I have been going to Chloe's for over 15 years and now live in London but visit SF often. It's a perfect little breakfast place with the main focus on honest good American breakfast. Having travelled and lived in many countries, I can only think of Taiwan as having as good a breakfast culture and quality as the U.S. 

Now, I really want to comment on Natalie W.'s review of Chloe's. Thanks for the internet, we get to hear diversity of a place like San Francisco. Almost all reviewers here love Chloe's but you get the odd few like Natalie's. It really shows that even in sophisticated, worldly San Francisco where citizens have probably the most advanced tastebuds in the country, there are still unsophisticated, ignorant people like Natalie that live this is great city. 

Omelettes are suppose to be runny. Go to any restaurant/cafe in Paris and that's how it's done. 

No egg substitutes is not only the standard in almost every country in the world, but in gastronomic destinations like France and Italy, you would be thrown out of the restaurant for asking for egg substitutes. Eggs are good natural and chefs/cooks appreciate and respect that. I'm glad a place in San Francisco (like many) are the same. 

What's funny is that Natalie lives in the Marina district. It's hilarious that someone who most likely has money is so unsophisticated and ignorant.
author: Tim T.

description:
First you stand on the sidewalk awkwardly, trying to avoid staring at the people eating delicious-looking food two feet from your face.

Then you sit, and try to enjoy your delicious food and ignore the people standing two feet from your plate.

But the wait aside, this place is good. Good scrambled eggs. Good walnut toast. Absolutely delicious croissant french toast with fresh strawberries and REAL maple syrup (the good stuff from Vermont). In the end, you feel it was worth the wait.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
The food was pretty good. The orange juice was fresh, and the coffee was good (although they served it in those wide-mouth shallow and totally impractical cups).

The spacing between the patrons as they ate was almost non-existant. It felt like I was in some magazine ad, where all the letters are typefaced bold and squashed with zero kerning. I'd say "yes" to "Wheelchair Accessible" with the caveat that your wheelchair must be narrower than 1 and 1/2 feet.

The wait to get seated was something short of amazing.
author: Jon G.

description:
Whenever I'd walk past Chloe's on my way out to Hungry Joe's at 30th and Church, I'd scratch my head as I eyeballed the wait of a dozen or more couples scattered about the sidewalk.  Why Chloe's always had a line out front and Joe's always had open stools at the counter was a question that perplexed me for years...till I took a ladyfriend here for Valentines day a year ago.  All of a sudden, the light turned on as to why people queue up 30 minutes deep to get a table here.....

Women just love the place.  They like the decor, they like the atmosphere, they like the attentive service mixed with a close, intimate, homey feel, and they like the artsy little touches that Chloe's adds to spruce up traditional Yankee breakfast fare.  Hungry Joe's gives a better bang-for-your-buck, but the choice of Chloe's is a no brainer if you're up for breakfast, not in a hurry, and a female sidekick is along for the ride.

I forgot what I she ordered...come to think of it, I forget what I ordered too. Valentines day fell during the week that year, and we went during off-peak hours so there wasn't a line.  My breakfast wasn't anything to complain about...but whatever touches they added to deviate it from the norm were things I saw as tolerable irritations rather than  meal-enhancing nuances. My feminine companion dug into her plate with an ear-to-ear grin, singing it's praises from start to finish.  I don't know how, but breakfast at Chloe's seemed to set the tone for a good day, kicking off a chain of events that kept us busy till nightfall.

People complain about the wait, but from what I've seen during my passings-by of Chloe's, the wait is an integral part of the dining experience on a nice day.  Numerous couples waiting for tables lounge idly on the sidewalk at 28th and Church, creating an interesting social scene that's highly interactive and extremely couples-centric.  The food is the same whether it's sunny or raining...but trust me...the length of the wait isn't.

If I'm hanging out with the fairer of our species, be she relative, friend, client, or romantic prospect, there's a good chance you might see me waiting with the other poor saps in front of Chloe's on a sunny spring morning.  In this situation, Chloe's is pretty dang hard to beat.  On the other hand, you  you'll NEVER see me here by myself.  In that instance, a gritty atmosphere, larger portions, and zero wait time await me at Herb's Fine Foods several blocks away.
author: Mike W.

description:
Cute little breakfast spot in Noe Valley.

The croissant french toast is very tasty, and the avocado and Jarlsberg scramble is not to be missed.  Fresh fruit really is fresh.  

Service is friendly, albeit a bit slow.  They could stand to wipe down the walls next to the tables - previous diners' coffee drips and tobasco splatters are readily viewable.

There's always a line out the door, and that's mostly because the restaurant seats 20-24 people max.  I had tried to get here earlier in the week, but the 6 twosomes waiting in front of me dissuaded me enough.

In sum, good place with good food, but I'm not left raving about it.
author: Evan G.

description:
Would be 5 stars except for the long wait! came here on a sunday afternoon and waited almost an hour for 2 people, so be warned. next time, we'll probably put our names on the list and walk around.

Food: the red potatoes scrambled eggs were tasty and definitely filling. especially with the croissants and home fries! (i'm on a high carb diet)

the bacon and tomato eggs were good but not terribly special. 

Definitely cute place/neighborhood in noe valley..
author: Kelly H.

description:
Met a few friends at this Noe Valley brunch spot today and wasn't disappointed. The line to get a table, inside or out, was about twenty minutes, but the staff was fast and efficient in getting us an inside table. 

Liked my peppermint tea and lemon zest/blueberry muffin to start, then followed by a red potato, cheese, and onion scramble with a side of fresh fruit. Pretty standard fare, but tasted good (despite the fact I have a cold) and was filling. Also ordered a side of crisp bacon, which was tasty too. A definite "yes" if you're looking for a new place for brunch!
author: David G.

description: I love Chloe's, and clearly I'm not the only one.  I usually come on a weekend and end up waiting at least 45 minutes before I get a table, but that's ok!  I wait because Chloe's is worth the wait.  The food is goooood.  My two favorite things on the menu are the tomato and bacon scramble (I always add feta cheese) with potatoes (no fruit plate for me), and the cinnamon croissant french toast with strawberries!  Yum!  Coffee is great, and I especially love that you get a lot of options when it comes to what kind of bread you want with your scramble.  There's your typical toast options, but then there's also rosemary bread and walnut bread, bagels or your choice of one of their fresh baked muffins.  Only downside is that they're cash only, so hit up an ATM before you head out for an amazing breakfast at Chloe's.
author: Victoria G.

description:
Everyone in Noe Valley has either a dog, a child under the age of 5 or both. I'm pretty sure it's a requirement for you to live there. 

The cafe is very small inside. Can probably only manage 10-15 people at any given time. 2-3 tables are usually set up outside on the sidewalk for busier days. Which for this place only takes about 3 families with fore mentioned dogs to take up all the space.

Food is good. I usually got the scambled eggs and fruit pancakes with a small shot of orange juice (if you've been here you know why I say "shot").
author: Gene C.

description:
Been coming here for years, and the wait has always been, well...LONG. I can't complain though, I try to come here every time I come back to the Bay. I miss the croissant french toast! Oh yes, the sausage is offered in chicken too. That's ALWAYS a great option! Outdoor seating is very lovely, and the neighborhood is very quaint. 

Overall, it's really grand to have this option if you're a local. As far as tourist, I'd save my time for something else. It's nothing to die for, but it's a great asset to have if you live close. I keep coming back for old times sake  =P.
author: Charles K.

description: Great place for breakfast. Be sure to give yourself time for the wait. The place can hold may be 50 people? There is also outside dining area (too cold for me in the morning). Food is good but a bit pricey (Noe Valley).  Will go back when in SF.
author: Ian W.

description:
This is the best restaurant I have found this year.

I had the croissant french toast topped with strawberries sprinkled with cinammon and powered sugar. The boyfriend had the blueberry pancakes. We both agreed that this was in the top 5 brunch places in the bay area.
author: Hayley L.

description: I get mixed reviews from friends I come here with, but they have thus far consistently been good for me.  the croissant French toast dish is different than most other places and is one of those things where you need to try at least once.  OJ and the Italian sausage make an excellent pairing to the French toast.
author: Wayne L.

description:
yummy.  lots o veggie choices.  But the crowd can suck, lots of yuppies and gaybies.  lame.......

P'ster
author: Pammy S.

description: This tasty delight satisfies all my breakfast needs. They provide plentiful, delicious food and I leave here with a big smile and a clean plate. The only drawback is that it is cash only and every time someone enters or exits there is a draft. I have lived in san Francisco for a month now and have already eaten here 4 times. I feel fortunate to live so close to such good breakfast.
author: Jenna K.

description: My friend brought me here after our morning bootcamp @ Dolores Park.  We got here around 1130ish and virtually no wait!  Maybe 5 mins tops!  I got the "special" of the day which was an omelet with mushrooms, bell peps, tomatoes and pesto. It tasted like a pizza and i absolutely loved it!  I had the wheat walnut bread...it was good!  Overall good b'fast!
author: Bravo J.

description:
I was excited to try this out in pursuit of the best brunch in SF and while I appreciated the solidly good and attentive service, I think there's better places more deserving of the recognition. 

We had a sandwich and omelette and it didn't stand out that much but it's a reliably good and affordable place to go if you live in the neighborhood. I do think there's better places, however.
author: Julia R.

description: good pricing and good food. I got a really tasty avocado and cheese omelette. my mom wasn't too crazy about her chicken apple sausage sandwich though.
author: Trucy N.

description: The best scrambled eggs I had were at a bed and breakfast in England.  Served over buttered toast, they were fluffy and melted in my mouth.  Chloe's scramble with smoked salmon comes a close second.
author: Sondra H.

description: Love this place.  Teeny Tiny and always packed but totally worth the wait.
author: Karen C.

description: I have been going to Chloe's for years, and finally decided, it's time. I don't know WHAT ON EARTH they do to the eggs, but it might be some kind of drug, or fairy dust. They taste like no other eggs I've had in my life. Ok, maybe it's just butter? I really have no clue-but they don't taste like any eggs I've had in my 37 years of life. Seriously, they're that good.  I always get the same thing, red potato onion scramble, but I've had bites of pancakes and other such delights like the french toast and they are all delicious as well. The line sucks, and they take cash only, but hey, there is something to be said for old school and it is worth the wait.
author: Margot G.

description: Small neighborhood cafe serving breakfast staples in a small and cozy environment.  I can't remember exactly what I got, maybe some sort of French Toast?  Everything looked good on the menu, but nothing looked great.  The portion size I remember as being just right, filing me up perfectly without regret.  Also the prices were reasonable for an SF breakfast spot.  I remember leaving and feeling that I was glad to have eaten, and feeling generally positive about my experience at Chloe's, but not enough to rave about.  If I am in the area and it is not the weekend (it is quite small inside and I am sure it gets swamped when busy) I will think about stopping by.
author: Kenneth H.

description:
I'm a little mystified by the popularity of this place.

The food is pretty decent, but nothing fantastic. Perhaps I would have enjoyed it more if we hadn't been seated next to an interminable yapper who clearly felt no qualms about airing her family's dirty laundry.
author: Holly T.

description: This place has the best bacon scrambled eggs! We got lucky and got there after the crowd had died down on a bright, sunny, yet breezy San Francisco day! The service was fast and friendly. The bathroom was quite possibly the smallest one I've ever seen (and I've seen some small ones) but it was clean. Love love love Noe Valley and Chloe's Cafe is one of the reasons why Noe rocks.
author: CT T.

description:
If you like pancakes or French toast, then honey, this is your home. If you enjoy heartier fare, keep walking. The axiom, 'Do one thing, and do it well' is in action here. You can only get scrambled eggs here, and you've made better sandwiches at home. It is humorous to see the hungover/pasty/trendy/baby-laden people, desperate to eat al fresco. 

In the time you've lost waiting for a spot, you could have picked up takeout somewhere better, and created a picnic in GG park.
author: Rene D.

description:
Wow, I suppose that neighborhood (Mission/Valencia "Corridor" to types who believe that's a hip name) considers restaurants that RESEAT YOU after BEING SEATED ALREADY on the whim of the staff is an OK standard for 'service'. Ugh. We went on a crowded morning (pick any weekend morning), were put on a list, got called from the list, seated, then subsequently asked to LEAVE our table as the 'name before us' hadn't heard her name being read, so THEY were seated instead. Huh? How does THAT logic work? Anyway, after a 45 minute wait, we were famished anyhoo, so stayed for the food against my better judgment. The food was good, but then again, I was VERY hungry at that point, so a PB&J sandwich would have sufficed. There are PLENTY of other yummy brunch places to go, so save your time, money, and frustration- steer clear of this place.
 
(Apologies for dissenting-- everyone else seem to be raving about it and i do not know why...)
author: M'ia K.

description:
They get docked one star because you always have to wait - always.

I must admit, the wait is worth it.  But, as Laura B. said, you will waste a good portion of what some might consider the early morning.

I really love the cinnamon croissant french toast with fresh strawberries (the berries are an add on).  They aren't big on picky orders but they do make my boyfriend his croissant sandwich by request.  The scrambles are really great if your into scrambles and the pancakes are delicious, but unless you can stomach all the ooey gooey sweetness I recommend sharing a short stack with the table.

Great place to bring visiting friends or to trek out to 'the morning after'.  You can look like a sleeze and still be given the best service.

The prices are also right and there is cute outdoor seating if you, much like me, are one of those people that like to bring your loyal pal - the pooch.

The fresh squeezed juices are also very re-hydrating.
author: Lauren G.

description: YUM YUM YUM!! My girlfriend and I tried Chloe's one Saturday based off yelp reviews and the fact that we both LOVE us some yummy brunchy goodness. We both love trying new and tasty places for brunch. The food was delicious. I had the cinnamon french toast, Aly had the asparagus scramble and we both had juice,water and coffee, breakfast potatoes and toast on the side...Basic breakfast but yummy,fresh and fast!! Will definitely go there again.
author: Kokoa L.

description: Noe Valley's most authentically local gem.  We've tried brunch pretty much everywhere else in the neighborhood and while I would argue you can get better at a select few spots elsewhere in the city (I have a special place in my heart for Mama's in North Beach - despite the tourists), Chloe's is tops for Noe.
author: Mitchell F.

description:
Very good frittata.  
Eggs looks awesome as well.
Not much queue for a late lunch.
author: Peter O.

description:
Fantastic brunch. Food is extremely fresh and reasonably light. The wait can be very long; I usually go elsewhere if it's too long. The food is good but not *that* good. Get coffee across the street to sip while you're waiting for a table. They have outdoor seating, so you can bring your dog on nice days.

[I ate brunch at Fattoush when the line at Chloe's was too long -- got an egg benedict that was soggy, gross, and that made me sick -- so I don't see it as a viable alternative to Chloe's.]
author: Ellen B.

description:
Uhmmm.... this place is okay.

I think it's really overrated.  Why are people waiting for three hours for a table here when they could just go down the street to Savor and get a bigger portion of food (just as tasty or tastier) in half the amount of time?

I DO enjoy Chloe's rosemary bread, though.  Yummy.
author: Sleuthy W.

description:
So far the best breakfast I have had in San Francisco.  Really speedy service and reasonable prices. If you don't want to wait don't go when everyone else and their dog goes. Go on a weekday morning.  I have actually only had to wait for a seat on the weekend and that was for 15 mins or so.

 IN A WORD YUMMY! word.
author: Greg D.

description:
Solid breakfast/brunch food. I came here recently with a group of seven others. The restaurant is small with seating both inside and outside. We waited about 45 minutes, which isn't tooo bad for a Saturday morning brunch in SF for a party of 8. 

Most of us ordered the croissant french toast or the scrambled eggs with Jarlsberg cheese and avocado and we all tried each others' food. The croissant french toast was fantastic. The eggs were also excellent. The fruit that came with my eggs were fresh and sweet. The home fries were nicely seasoned and tasty. The pancakes were extremely fluffy and delicious. We were all very full and very content at the end of the meal.

A great brunch spot.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I really have no complaints about this place.  The home fries are delicious.  the pancakes were good. the scramble was most excellent.  The wait was a bit long, but it's b/c this place is so small.  

All their food looks great.  I can't wait to go back and try their other items.  I'm serious about this place being small.  I don't recommend going in big groups.  this place is small and quaint.  my friend and I had a lovely time here today.
author: AhLin C.

description: The place is located in a cozy, small and nice environment. I wanted to eat an American Breakfast and i live pretty close by which is really convenient. There is outdoor seats and luckily it was really sunny day so i really enjoyed breakfast there. The food was great. I had the specialties, the croissant with tomato and cheese, the brie was delicious! Absolutely loved it! Although i think the price may be a little too much, i think once in a while its a good place to try:) Doesn't accept credit cards so better bring your cash when you're planning to eat here.
author: Cavin T.

description: This place is always worth the wait. I love the local feel. It has an honest San Francisco vibe. I would definitely recommend Chloe's for breakfast/brunch for entertaining out of town guests.
author: Melody H.

description:
Two word...Poe tatos.

They are the best I have had...and consistantly the best.  That is why I gave Chloe's 5 stars.  Eggs, french toast, everything else is good.  But potatoes is why I go here.
author: Keith J.

description:
A few friends and I had brunch here on Saturday, first time visitors for all of us. We were all impressed.

Their egg scramble special was deeelicious, perfectly cooked & super flavorful. My friends seemed to enjoy their smoked salmon eggs and the better known banana walnut pancakes. If you're looking for a lazy day, enjoy a few of their mimosas. 

Service was great. Really great. I liked the sidewalk table atmosphere. 

Be prepared for a wait on a Saturday morning, especially when you've got a perfect weather day. But if the wait really is too much, there's a Med restaurant just a few doors down with some cool looking outside patio tables.
author: Karina K.

description:
At first glance, I was disappointed by their limited brunch menu, but after ordering, I realized that scrambled eggs is their core competency, and they stick to it.  French toast soaked all the way through, which is a rare find. Too bad there was no Belgian waffle on the menu.

Recommend: scrambled with feta

Also, easy to put your name in the queue, and wait or walk around. The inside is small and chatty, but not irritatingly so.
author: Mehul P.

description:
Fresh corn in the eggs! A+ everything. And I like the surly waitstaff. This place is a good reason to call in sick on a Monday morning.
Also, waiting in line provides excellent eavesdropping ops. not unlike reading US.
author: Caitlin P.

description:
You Yelpers were right -- good breakfast spot if you can wait out the line. 

The homefries are great.  The coffee ("Magic blend," our waitress told us) is delicious.  The pancakes are fluffy and tasty.  

Very cute spot.  You can't call in a reservation.  If you're considering brunch, get here before 10am.  By 10am on the weekends, there'll be 30 people standing out front with their names on the list.  And you don't want to sit outside unless it's Indian summer or just a glorious sunny day, so you'll be waiting (AT LEAST) 30 minutes for a spot, and plan to wait more.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
I won't go and wait in line to eat there, but during the weekdays you can usually walk right in and be seated and I've found the food to be pretty good across the board and the servings fine, not huge, but good.  

I usually just get something simple like an egg dish with a bowl of fruit and it is well done, but the potatoes have a bit of crispy-ness that I appreciate, too.

The staff is extremely nice and the food comes quickly.

The weekend scene is different - long waits, lots of those jogging-strollers and dogs out front with everyone talking about their house remodel projects.  You watch as people continue to sit at their tables long after all the food and drinks have been cleared to socialize while flocks of people wait outside, which never seems super considerate to the people waiting, or to the staff that count on turnover to make their wages.

Breakfast for two runs in the $25 range.
author: Doug M.

description:
Agreeing with the other reviews, the scramble with salmon was very average. Had to wait 20 minutes on Boxing Day, lots of snooty white Noe types. Why no fried eggs option? Not much choice to speak off. The croissant French toast rescued my breakfast experience, I like the stodgy thick style rather than fluffy or rubbery of other places. The latte was not bad, but not enough either. Did give me a  coffee refill for free on my latte.
Other than that, no reason to travel across town for this and there are other local options. If I lived two blocks away I might be prepared to wait in line...
author: Shad M.

description:
I've been eating at Chloe's since before I moved to SF. I love the food and the charm this place has to offer. It probably has the smallest kitchen in San Francisco. Hence, I can completely understand why they don't take specilty orders. We all ordered something special then the wait to get in would be ten times longer.
